question: Three identical slender rods each of mass M are welded at their ends to form an equilateral triangle, and the corners are then welded to a light metal hoop of radius R. If the rigid assembly of rods and hoop is allowed to roll down the incline of inclination θ, the minimum value of the coefficient of static friction is μ that will prevent slipping. Then find the value of 10μ.
text:
Three identical slender rods each of mass M are welded at their ends to form an equilateral
triangle, and the corners are then welded to a light metal hoop of radius R. If the rigid assembly
of rods and hoop is allowed to roll down the incline of inclination θ, the minimum value of the
coefficient of static friction is μ that will prevent slipping. Then find the value of 10μ.$Image not present$
html: Three identical slender rods each of mass M are welded at their ends to form an equilateral triangle, and the corners are then welded to a light metal hoop of radius R. If the rigid assembly of rods and hoop is allowed to roll down the incline of inclination θ, the minimum value of the coefficient of static friction is μ that will prevent slipping. Then find the value of 10μ.

question: A block slides down an inclined plane of angle ϕ with constant velocity v0. If it is then projected up the same inclined plane with an initial sped v0 , the distance in which it will come to rest is :
options: {"0": "", "1": "", "2": "", "3": ""}
text:
A block slides down an inclined plane of angle ϕ with constant velocity v0. If it is then projected up the same inclined plane with an initial sped v0 , the distance in which it will come to rest is :

$\frac{{v_0^2}}{{g\,\tan \,\phi }}$
$\frac{{v_0^2}}{{4\,g\,\sin \,\phi }}$
$\frac{{v_0^2}}{{2\,g}}$
$\frac{{v_0^2}}{{2\,g\,\sin \,\phi }}$

question: A block is placed on a rough plank moving with velocity  and velocity of block relative to plank is . Find unit vector in  direction of kinetic friction force acting on the block is :-
options: {"0": "", "1": "", "2": "", "3": ""}
text:
A block is placed on a rough plank moving with velocity $3\hat j$ and velocity of block relative to plank is $3\hat i + 4\hat j$. Find unit vector in  direction of kinetic friction force acting on the block is :-


$\dfrac{{ - (3\hat i + \hat j)}}{{\sqrt {10} }}$
$\dfrac{{ - (3\hat i + 4\hat j)}}{5}$
$\dfrac{{(3\hat i + 4\hat j)}}{5}$
$\dfrac{{3\hat i + \hat j}}{{\sqrt {10} }}$

question: A massless rod of length L has masses m1 attached to each end. The rod is free to rotate on the surface of a frictionless table about a hinge attached to its center C. A mass m2 is moving across the table at speed v perpendicular to the rod and is aimed directly at one of the masses m1 as shown in the diagram. At time t = 0, m2 collides with m1 and sticks instantaeously, setting the rod into rotation about C. m1 = 1 kg, m2 = 2kg, v = 12 m/s, L = 4m. What is the angular velocity just after the collision, (in rad/s)

question: A small disk is attached to the end of a light inextensible string, which passes through a hole in a frictionless horizontal tabletop. Initially the disk moves on a circle of radius R with kinetic energy K0. The string is then slowly pulled so that the disk finally rotates on a circle of radius R/η. What is the work W done in pulling the string ?
text:
A small disk is attached to the end of a light inextensible string, which passes through a hole in a frictionless horizontal tabletop. Initially the disk moves on a circle of radius R with kinetic energy K0. The string is then slowly pulled so that the disk finally rotates on a circle of radius R/η. What is the work W done in pulling the string ?
$Image not present$

W = η2K0
W = (η2 – 1)K0
W = (η – 1)K0
W = 0
html:
A small disk is attached to the end of a light inextensible string, which passes through a hole in a frictionless horizontal tabletop. Initially the disk moves on a circle of radius R with kinetic energy K0. The string is then slowly pulled so that the disk finally rotates on a circle of radius R/η. What is the work W done in pulling the string ?

W = η2K0
W = (η2 – 1)K0
W = (η – 1)K0
W = 0

question: A particle of mass m moving in XY horizontal plane strikes the end of the vertical rod at an angle 37° with Y-axis. Rod has mass m and length  and it is free to rotate about hinge along Y-axis. If particle strikes rod with speed u and sticks to it, find the CORRECT choice(s).
options:
{"0": "Velocity of particle just after impact will be\u00a0", "1": "Velocity of particle just after impact will be\u00a0", "2": "
Minimum speed so that rod completes full rotation about hinge is\u00a0
\n", "3": "Angular momentum of system during collision is conserved about Y-axis."}
text:
A particle of mass m moving in XY horizontal plane strikes the end of the vertical rod at an angle 37° with Y-axis. Rod has mass m and length  and it is free to rotate about hinge along Y-axis. If particle strikes rod with speed u and sticks to it, find the CORRECT choice(s).


Velocity of particle just after impact will be $ - \frac{{4u\hat i}}{5} + \frac{{9u\hat j}}{5}$
Velocity of particle just after impact will be $ - \frac{{9u\hat i}}{{20}} + \frac{{4u\hat j}}{{10}}$
Minimum speed so that rod completes full rotation about hinge is $\frac{{10}}{3}\sqrt {2g\ell } $

Angular momentum of system during collision is conserved about Y-axis.

question: Two identical blocks are resting on supports as shown. Two identical bullets travelling with the same speed hit the blocks & get embedded in them in very short time. The blocks leave the contact immediately after bullet strikes them. In case (i) bullet's velocity is toward centre of mass and in case (ii) bullet's velocity is off centre. The kinetic energies after collision are K1 & K2 and maximum height reached by the centre of mass are h1 & h2 respectively. Then :
options: {"0": "K<sub>1</sub> < K<sub>2</sub>", "1": "K<sub>1</sub> = K<sub>2</sub>", "2": "h<sub>1</sub> > h<sub>2</sub>", "3": "h<sub>1</sub> = h<sub>2</sub>"}
text:
Two identical blocks are resting on supports as shown. Two identical bullets travelling with the same
speed hit the blocks & get embedded in them in very short time. The blocks leave the contact immediately
after bullet strikes them. In case (i) bullet's velocity is toward centre of mass and in case (ii) bullet's
velocity is off centre. The kinetic energies after collision are K1 & K2 and maximum height reached by
the centre of mass are h1 & h2 respectively. Then :$Image not present$

K1 < K2
K1 = K2
h1 > h2
h1 = h2
html:
Two identical blocks are resting on supports as shown. Two identical bullets travelling with the same speed hit the blocks & get embedded in them in very short time. The blocks leave the contact immediately after bullet strikes them. In case (i) bullet's velocity is toward centre of mass and in case (ii) bullet's velocity is off centre. The kinetic energies after collision are K1 & K2 and maximum height reached by the centre of mass are h1 & h2 respectively. Then :


K1 < K2
K1 = K2
h1 > h2
h1 = h2

question:
Two vectors  and  add to give a resultant . In which of these cases angle between  and  is maximum: 
(a, b, c represent the magnitudes of respective vectors)
options:
{"0": "
c = a + b
", "1": "
c2 = a2 + b2
", "2": "
c = a – b
", "3": "

text:
Two vectors $\vec a$ and $\vec b$ add to give a resultant $\vec c = \vec a + \vec b$. In which of these cases angle between $\vec a$ and $\vec b$ is maximum: 
(a, b, c represent the magnitudes of respective vectors)

c = a + b

c2 = a2 + b2

c = a – b

can not be determined

question: A rigid triangular frame consists of three massless rods of length ℓ = 2.5 m each and point masses of mass m each at vertex B and C respectively. Frame is hanging vertically from point A about which it can rotate freely about an axis xx' which is perpendicular to plane of frame as shown in figure. Point of suspension of frame, i.e. A, is accelerating with constant acceleration a = 3g/4 in horizontal direction and initially frame is at rest w.r.t. support A. Minimum initial angular velocity ω = x(3)1/4 (in rad/s) provided to system, so that it can complete vertical circular motion in the frame of support A. Calculate the value of x. (take g = 10 m/s2)
text:
A rigid triangular frame consists of three massless rods of length ℓ = 2.5 m each and point masses of
mass m each at vertex B and C respectively. Frame is hanging vertically from point A about which it
can rotate freely about an axis xx' which is perpendicular to plane of frame as shown in figure. Point
of suspension of frame, i.e. A, is accelerating with constant acceleration a = 3g/4 in horizontal direction
and initially frame is at rest w.r.t. support A. Minimum initial angular velocity ω = x(3)1/4 (in rad/s)
provided to system, so that it can complete vertical circular motion in the frame of support A. Calculate
the value of x. (take g = 10 m/s2)$Image not present$

question: A force  acts on a particle at . The torque  acting on the particle relative to a point with co-ordinates (2.0 m, 0, –3.0 m) is
options:
{"0": "
", "1": "
", "2": "
", "3": "
"}
text:
A force $\vec F = 2\hat i - 3\hat k$ acts on a particle at $\vec r = 0.5\hat j - 2\hat k$. The torque $\vec \tau $ acting on the particle relative to a point with co-ordinates (2.0 m, 0, –3.0 m) is        

$( - 3.0\hat i - 4.5\hat j - \hat k)N - m$

$(3\hat i + 6\hat j - \hat k)N - m$

$( - 20\hat i + 4.0\hat j + \hat k)N - m$

$( - 1.5\hat i - 4.0\hat j - \hat k)N - m$

question: A solid sphere is given an angular velocity ω and kept on a rough fixed incline plane. Then choose the CORRECT statement(s).
options:
{"0": "
If μ = tan θ then sphere will be in linear equilibrium for some time and after that pure rolling down the plane will start.
", "1": "If μ = tan θ then sphere will move up the plane and frictional force acting all the time will be 2 mg sinθ.", "2": "If μ = there will never be pure rolling (consider inclined plane to be long enough.)
", "3": "
If incline plane is not fixed and it is on smooth horizontal surface then linear momentum of the system (wedge and sphere) can be conserved in horizontal direction.
"}
text:
A solid sphere is given an angular velocity ω and kept on a rough fixed incline plane. Then choose the CORRECT statement(s).$Image not present$

If μ = tan θ then sphere will be in linear equilibrium for some time and after that pure
rolling down the plane will start.
If μ = tan θ then sphere will move up the plane and frictional force acting all the time will
be 2 mg sinθ.
If μ = $Image not present$ there will never be pure rolling (consider inclined plane to be long enough.)
If incline plane is not fixed and it is on smooth horizontal surface then linear momentum
of the system (wedge and sphere) can be conserved in horizontal direction.
html:
A solid sphere is given an angular velocity ω and kept on a rough fixed incline plane. Then choose the CORRECT statement(s).



If μ = tan θ then sphere will be in linear equilibrium for some time and after that pure rolling down the plane will start.
If μ = tan θ then sphere will move up the plane and frictional force acting all the time will be 2 mg sinθ.
If μ = there will never be pure rolling (consider inclined plane to be long enough.)
If incline plane is not fixed and it is on smooth horizontal surface then linear momentum of the system (wedge and sphere) can be conserved in horizontal direction.
error_induced_html:
A solid sphere is given an angular velocity ω and kept on a rough fixed incline plane. Then choose the CORRECT statement(s).



If μ = tan θ then sphere will be in linear equilibrium for some time and after that pure rolling down the plane will start.
If μ = tan θ then sphere will move up the plane and frictional force acting all the time will be 2 mg sinθ.
If μ = there will never be pure rolling (consider inclined plane to be long enough.)
If incline plane is not fixed and it is on smooth horizontal surface then linear momentum of the system (wedge and sphere) can be conserved in horizontal direction.
error_corrected_html:
A solid sphere is given an angular velocity ω and kept on a rough fixed incline plane. Then choose the CORRECT statement(s).



If μ = tan θ, then the sphere will be in linear equilibrium for some time and after that pure rolling down the plane will start.
If μ = tan θ, then the sphere will move up the plane and the frictional force acting all the time will be 2 mg sinθ.
If μ = there will never be pure rolling (consider inclined plane to be long enough.)
If the incline plane is not fixed and it is on a smooth horizontal surface, then the linear momentum of the system (wedge and sphere) can be conserved in the horizontal direction.

question: A uniform rod of mass M = 2 kg and length L is suspended by two smooth hinges 1 and 2 as shown in the figure. A force F = 4N is applied downward at a distance from the hinge 2. Due to the application of force F, the hinge 2 breaks. At this instant, applied force F is also removed. The rod starts to rotate downward about hinge 1. (g = 10 m/s2). Choose the correct statement(s) :-
options: {"0": "The reaction at hinge 1, before hinge 2 breaks, is 11 N", "1": "The reaction at hinge 1, before hinge 2 breaks, is 24 N", "2": "The reaction at hinge 1, just after breaking of hinge 2 is 5 N", "3": "The reaction at hinge 1, just after breaking of hinge 2 is 8 N"}
text:
A uniform rod of mass M = 2 kg and length L is suspended by two smooth hinges 1 and 2 as shown in the figure. A force F = 4N is applied downward at a distance $Image not present$ from the hinge 2. Due to the application of force F, the hinge 2 breaks. At this instant, applied force F is also removed. The rod starts to rotate downward about hinge 1. (g = 10 m/s2). $Image not present$

The reaction at hinge 1, before hinge 2 breaks, is 24 N
The reaction at hinge 1, just after breaking of hinge 2 is 5 N

question: Two equal uniform rods P and Q move with the same velocity v as shown in the figure. The second rod has an angular velocity ω (<6v/l) (clockwise) about G' in addition to v.
options: {"0": "If the ends A & A' are suddenly fixed simultaneously both rods will rotate with the same angular velocity", "1": "If the ends A & A' are suddenly fixed simultaneously, the rod Q will rotate with greater angular velocity", "2": "If the ends B & B' are suddenly fixed simultaneously both rods will rotate with the same angular velocity", "3": "If the ends B & B' are suddenly fixed simultaneously, the rod P will rotate with greater angular velocity"}
text:
Two equal uniform rods P and Q move with the same velocity v as shown in the figure. The second rod has an angular velocity ω (<6v/l) (clockwise) about G' in addition to v.
$Image not present$

If the ends A & A' are suddenly fixed simultaneously both rods will rotate with the same angular velocity
If the ends A & A' are suddenly fixed simultaneously, the rod Q will rotate with greater angular velocity
If the ends B & B' are suddenly fixed simultaneously both rods will rotate with the same angular velocity
If the ends B & B' are suddenly fixed simultaneously, the rod P will rotate with greater angular velocity

The springs are fixed to rigid supports as shown in the figure, and the rod is free to oscillate in the horizontal plane. The rod is gently pushed through a small angle q in one direction and released. The frequency of oscillation is :-

text:
A uniform rod of length L and mass M is pivoted at the centre. Its two ends are attached to two springs of equal spring constants k. The springs are fixed to rigid supports as shown in the figure, and the rod is free to oscillate in the horizontal plane. The rod is gently pushed through a small angle q in one direction and released. The frequency of oscillation is :-


$\frac{1}{{2\pi }}\sqrt {\frac{{2k}}{M}} $

$\frac{1}{{2\pi }}\sqrt {\frac{k}{M}} $

$\frac{1}{{2\pi }}\sqrt {\frac{{6k}}{M}} $

$\frac{1}{{2\pi }}\sqrt {\frac{{24k}}{M}} $

Ring of mass m and radius R is attached with a particle of mass m at its rim has 4 cases as shown. Centre of ring has some velocity, and angular velocity is ω = . An external variable force couple acts on ring in such a way to keep angular velocity ω constant. When N1, N2, N3 & N4 are normal reactions between smooth ground and ring, then choose correct alternatives.
 
  Column I   Column II
A  N1 P  2 mg
B  N2 Q  5 mg
C  N3 R  4 mg
D  N4 S  3 mg
    T  mg

(KE)B – (KE)A = 0 (KE = kinetic energy)

question: A particle is moving with a uniform speed in a circular orbit of radius R under the influence of a central force inversely proportional to the nth power of R. If angular velocity of particle is ω, then :-
options:
{"0": "
", "1": "
", "2": "
", "3": "

text:
A particle is moving with a uniform speed in a circular orbit of radius R under the influence of a central force inversely proportional to the nth power of R. If angular velocity of particle is ω, then :-

$\omega  \propto {R^{\dfrac{{n + 1}}{2}}}$

$\omega  \propto {R^{ - \left( {\dfrac{{n + 1}}{2}} \right)}}$

$\omega  \propto {R^{\dfrac{n}{2}}}$

$\omega  \propto {R^{ - \dfrac{n}{2}}}$

question: A rod of mass M and length L is placed in a horizontal plane with one end hinged about the vertical axis. A horizontal force of  is applied at a distance  from the hinged end perpendicular to rod. The angular acceleration of the rod will be:
options:
{"0": "
", "1": "
", "2": "
", "3": "
"}
text:
A rod of mass M and length L is placed in a horizontal plane with one end hinged about the vertical axis. A horizontal force of $F = \frac{{Mg}}{2}$ is applied at a distance $\frac{{5L}}{6}$ from the hinged end perpendicular to rod. The angular acceleration of the rod will be:

$\frac{{4g}}{{5L}}$

$\frac{{5g}}{{4L}}$

$\frac{{3g}}{{4L}}$

$\frac{{4g}}{{3L}}$

A  A ring of mass m is projected on rough horizontal plane with velocity v0. The magnitude of work done by frictional force to start rolling
P

Q  
C  Kinetic energy of translation of a smooth rod of mass m, where velocity of one end is v0.
